sen.e: The first Kento-shi was sent to Tang in 630 with INUGAMI no Mitasuki as its chief.
The first Kento-shi was sent to Tang China in 630 with INUGAMI no Mitasuki as its chief.

sen.j: 貞観5年、使いを遣わして方物を献ず。
sen.e: In 863, an envoy was sent to pay tributes.

sen.j: 太宗、その道の遠きを矜（あわれ）み、所司に勅して、歳貢せしむることなからしむ。
sen.e: Taiso felt pity for the envoy taking a long voyage to Tang, and ordered an officer in charge to spare the tributes of every year.
Taiso felt worried for the envoy taking a long voyage to Tang, and ordered an officer in charge to spare the tributes of every year.

sen.j: 貞観5年（631年）に倭国は使者を派遣して、入貢し方物を献じたが、太宗は、倭国は遠い国であるから、毎年朝貢する必要はない、と担当の役所に命じた、という。
sen.e: In 631, Wakoku deployed an envoy to pay tributes to the King of Tang, but Taiso (Tang tai zong, the second Emperor of Tang) said to the office in charge that as Wakoku is located far from Tang, it does not need to pay tributes every year'.

sen.j: 明は諸外国の国王名義の表文を持参した国家に対してのみ勘合貿易（朝貢貿易）を認め、それが無い場合には貿易を拒否した。
sen.e: The Ming Dynasty China permitted the tally trade only to the countries which brought a Johyobun with King's signature on it to Ming but otherwise refused to trade with any other countries.

sen.cmt: この場合はMing Dynasty (China不要）で良いと思われます。tally tradeは初出なのでtheを取りました。「any other countries」は不要と思われたので取りました。

sen.j: 足利義満も「日本国王」として明の皇帝永楽帝に表文を送った。
sen.e: Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA was one of those who sent a Johyobun as King of Japan to Emperor Yongle of Ming.
Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA was one of those who sent a Johyobun as King of Japan to Emperor Yongle of Ming.

sen.j: 『善隣国宝記』によれば、「日本国王 臣源表(す)」から始まる中国の伝統的な表文の形式に則っており、これに対して永楽帝は「日本国王之印」を授けている。
sen.e: According to the "Zenrin kokuhoki", the letter started with '日本国王 臣源表(す)' in accordance with the traditional form of a Chinese official letter and Emperor Yongle conferred the 'seal of the king of Japan' to him in return.
sen.cmt: 日本国王 臣源表(す)：意味が不明です。

sen.j: 古事記の選者太安万侶（おおのやすまろ ?-723）が奉ったとされている序文も上表文である。
sen.e: The preface, which a compiler of Kojiki, O no Yasumaro (c. - 723), is believed to have presented to the Emperor, was also written in the form of Johyobun.
The preface, which a compiler of Kojiki, O no Yasumaro (c. - 723), has been believed to have presented to the Emperor, is also considered as Johyobun.
sen.cmt: is→has beenにしました。？→c.でよいでしょうか。Was written in the form of→is also considered asとしました。（前列の記述より、上表文は書式ではなく文そのものとみなせるので。）
sen.e: The preface, which a compiler of Kojiki, O no Yasumaro (? - 723), has been believed to have presented to the Emperor, is also considered as Johyobun.
